candidates.title: Update dependencies and apply linter suggestions
store cluster metrics in a simpler way, query them all
candidates.body:
Continuation of #783 

This pull request removes what @Geal started to work on but didn't finish.
The cluster metrics are now stored without timestamps, which reduces
the strain on the memory and thus is cleared only everyday at midgnight.
They are stored in a simple binary tree map of the form
`cluster_or_backend_id -> (key, value)`

The relation between is clusters and backend is tracked in another map of the form `backend_id -> cluster_id `

This pull request removes the option to enable the timed collection of metrics.

## to do
- [x] queries for cluster and backend metrics, providing their ids and metric names.
- [x] error management on cluster & backend ids provided by the CLI
- [x] error management alltogether

solves #790  #789

candidates.title: fix metrics
candidates.body:
For now, when we query metrics… nothing appears. Also metrics enabling and disabling doesn't work.

Let's fix it.

- [x] fix "metrics enable" and disable and clear
- [x] fix "query metrics" to display something

This is done, but… it appears @Geal did not finish to implement all intended features on metrics. Left to do:

- [x] recreate a proper general output for all metrics (percentiles, nice tables)
- [ ] decomment and bring to life the commented code of `dump_cluster_data()`
- [ ] check if the cluster and backend ids provided in the command line actually exist, send an error if not.

The unchecked boxes will be handled other issues & pull requests.

candidates.title: Update command, lib and binaries dependencies
add a custom-tag field to all front-ends
candidates.body:
solves #756 

We want to attach custom tags to all sorts of frontends: HTTP, HTTPS, TCP in order to better retrieve them in the access logs.

There are roughly four steps in doing so, as described by @FlorentinDUBOIS:

- [x] adding the `custom_tag` field to all front-end definitions, to the command line interface, etc
- [x] retrieving the custom tags in the big server loop
- [x] inject them in the `Session` structure
- [x] pass them to the underlying `Http<Front>` wich creates the access logs with the `info_access!` macro

candidates.title: 0.14 socket connection error management
candidates.body:
As mentioned in

- #721 

We have a nasty `panic!` when trying to connect to a unix socket that isn't there.

```
thread 'main' panicked at 'could not connect to the command unix socket: Os { code: 111, kind: ConnectionRefused, message: "Connection refused" }', bin/src/ctl/mod.rs:37:43
```

This pull request fixes it with `anyhow` and its `Context` that make a much nicer (and more traceable) error management:

```
Error: could not connect to the command unix socket

Caused by:
    0: Could not create Channel from the given path
    1: Connection refused (os error 111)

```

candidates.title: Simplify event loop
candidates.body:
this PR inverts the relation between the Proxy and Session structs, to remove responsibilities from the event loop.

In the previous architecture, whenever a session needed to handle routing, connecting to a backend, or closing a socket, it would return a `SessionResult` to the event loop, which would interpret it and perform the action, like deregistering a socket removing a session from the slab and call the session's `close()` method. If it required routing decision, it would call the (http, https or tcp) Proxy's `connect_to_backend` method with the session as argument, and the Proxy would handle routing and modify the session's fields as needed.
This design was quite complicated to follow, and too rigid for future features of sessions (like having multiple backend connections in HTTP/2 proxying).

The new design works as follows:
- sessions hold a `Rc<RefCell<Proxy>>`, and can call on them for routing info
- the `ProxyConfiguration` and `ProxySession` were reduced, since now a lot of their methods are handled internally between Session and Proxy, and the event loop does not need  to know about them
- a `SessionManager` struct is shared between the event loop and the `Proxy` to give access to the sessions slab and mio's registry

candidates.title: Error management in sozuctl
candidates.body:
The idea is to get rid of `expect`s and `unwrap`s in `command.rs` of `sozuctl` in the spirit of #317 

What I've done is use [anyhow](https://docs.rs/anyhow/1.0.42/anyhow/index.html) to **change all stderr logging and 1-exiting into [anyhow::bail!](https://docs.rs/anyhow/1.0.42/anyhow/macro.bail.html)**

```rust
eprintn!("some error occured");
exit(1);
```

becomes

```rust
bail!("some error occured");
```

This and the use of [anyhow::context](https://docs.rs/anyhow/1.0.42/anyhow/trait.Context.html#) makes for a smoother error handling.

HOWEVER, the use of the `command_timeout!` macro, that spawns a task and bails if the timeout is reached, becomes more complicated because the return type of the invoked code blocks must be **strictly** defined.
